items.title: Pine Barrens (Season 3, Episode 11)
items.description: Christopher and Paulie get lost in the snowy Pine Barrens while trying to dispose of a Russian mobster who refuses to die. This darkly comic episode showcases the show's ability to blend tension with humor.

items.title: College (Season 1, Episode 5)
items.description: Tony takes Meadow on a college tour but spots a former associate in witness protection. The episode perfectly balances Tony's roles as both a caring father and a ruthless criminal.

items.title: Long Term Parking (Season 5, Episode 12)
items.description: Adriana's fate is sealed in one of the series' most heartbreaking episodes. The emotional impact and shocking conclusion make this unforgettable.

items.title: Whitecaps (Season 4, Episode 13)
items.description: Tony and Carmela's marriage reaches a breaking point in this explosive season finale. The raw emotional performances elevate an already powerful script.

items.title: Made in America (Season 6, Episode 21)
items.description: The controversial series finale that sparked endless debate. The final scene at Holsten's diner remains one of television's most discussed endings.

items.title: Tony Soprano
items.description: The complex protagonist who redefined the TV antihero. James Gandolfini's portrayal of a violent mobster struggling with anxiety and depression created television history.

items.title: Dr. Jennifer Melfi
items.description: Tony's psychiatrist who provides a moral compass and allows the audience insight into Tony's psyche. Her ethical struggles mirror the show's moral complexity.

items.title: Christopher Moltisanti
items.description: Tony's nephew and protégé whose ambitions and addictions lead to tragic consequences. His character arc is one of the series' most compelling.

items.title: Livia Soprano
items.description: Tony's manipulative mother whose psychological abuse shaped Tony's personality. Nancy Marchand created one of television's most memorable villains.

items.title: Paulie Walnuts
items.description: The superstitious, volatile capo whose dark humor and unpredictability made him a fan favorite. Tony Sirico brought authenticity and menace to the role.

items.title: "Forget about it!"
items.description: The quintessential Italian-American expression that can mean anything depending on context. Used throughout the series by multiple characters.

items.title: "Those who want respect, give respect."
items.description: Tony's code of honor that he frequently invokes, though he doesn't always follow it himself.

items.title: "A wrong decision is better than indecision."
items.description: Tony's pragmatic philosophy about leadership and action, often used to justify his choices.

items.title: "I wipe my ass with your feelings."
items.description: Ralph Cifaretto's callous response that exemplifies the brutal nature of mob relationships.

items.title: "You know who had an ark? Noah."
items.description: Tony's response to Paulie's complaints about getting passed over, showing his dark sense of humor.
